entry.title: Non-thermal Particle from Maximum Entropy
entry.content:
Recent works proposed a novel model to account for the power-law non-thermal particle accelerated in turbulence (Zhdankin 2022a, 2022b).

Casimir Invariants and Casimir Momentum

The Vlasov equation gives the dynamical evolution of collisionless plasma,

\[\begin{equation} \partial _t f + v \cdot \nabla f = -F\cdot \frac{\partial f}{\partial p} \end{equation}\]

where LHS is the convective derivative, and RHS is the force, including the EM term and external term. \(f\) is the particle distribution function.

For a rising function \(g(f)\) with good enough properties, \(\frac{1}{N}\int d^3x d^3p g(f)\) is conserved, as long as f is described by Vlasov equation. Thus a set of \(g(f)\) is called Casimir invariants. A special invariant is found with dimension of momentum: the so called Casimir momentum.

\[\begin{equation} p_{c,\chi}(f) = n_0^{1/3} \left(\frac{1}{N} \int d^3x d^3p f^\chi\right) ^{-\frac{1}{3(\chi-1)}}, \end{equation}\]

where \(\chi>0\) is a free index. The Casimir momentum is equivalent with the Renyi entropy in its integral of phase space, and thus is a generalized entropy. Spacial inhomogeneity will result in decrease of the entropy, while energy injection will produce entropy.

Power-Law Particle

With particle number conservation and energy conservation, and from the maximal entropy condition, it naturally leads to a power-law particle spectrum:

\[\begin{equation} f = C[E(p)/E_b+1]^{-\frac{1}{1-\chi_d}} ,\end{equation}\]

where \(E_b\) and \(C\) is the normalization factor from the Lagrange multipliers.

In relativistic limit, there is

\[\begin{equation} f\xrightarrow{\text{UR}}C(p/p_b+1)^{-\alpha-2} ,\end{equation}\]

where \(\alpha = (2\chi_d-1)/(1-\chi_d)\)

In non-relativistic limit, there is

\[\begin{equation} f\xrightarrow{\text{NR}}C(p^2/p_b^2+1)^{-\alpha-1/2} ,\end{equation}\]

where \(\alpha = (\chi_d+1)/2(1-\chi_d)\).

For \(\chi=1\), \(f\) returns to the thermal distribution.

Comparing the maximal \(p_{c,\chi_d}\) with the \(p_{c,\infty}\), the physical condition corresponding to certain \(\alpha\) is

\[\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \eta \left(\frac{\delta B}{B_0}\right)^2\frac{1}{\beta_c} = & \left(\frac{\alpha+1}{\alpha-2}\right)^{\frac{\alpha+2}{3}}-e\\ \eta \left(\frac{\delta B}{B_0}\right)^2\frac{1}{\beta_c} = & \left(\frac{\alpha-1/2}{\alpha-2}\right)^{\frac{2\alpha+1}{3}}-e \end{aligned}, \end{equation}\]

for relativistic and non-relativistic cases respectively. \(\alpha\) is the particle SED power-law slope, \(\left(\frac{\delta B}{B_0}\right)^2\) is the strength of turbulence, \(\eta\) and \(e\) are coefficients with \(E_{c,\chi_d} \sim eE_0 + \eta F_{\mathrm{free}}\).

Summary

In these works, one of the Casimir invariants is considered, which has the same dimension with momentum. This invariant is related to the Gibbs entropy. From the argument that entropy is maximized in a system, this model naturally produces a power-law particle distribution. Because the Casimir momentum is physically meaningful, physical conditions could be roughly estimated for non-thermal particles with given power-law slope.

entry.title: Generalized Fermi Acceleration Reading Note
entry.content:
Electro-magnetic field is boosted to the frame in which electric field vanishes. This frame is not necessarily coincident with the fluid comoving frame unless ideal MHD is assumed. In the particle comoving frame, the kinetic equation is written as

\[\begin{equation} \frac{\mathrm{d} \hat{p}^{\hat{a}}}{\mathrm{d}\tau} = \frac{q}{m} \hat{F}^{\hat{a}} _{\hat{ b}}\hat{p}^{\hat{b}} - \hat{\Gamma}^{\hat{a}}_{\hat{b}\hat{c}}\frac{\hat{p}^{\hat{b}}\hat{p}^{\hat{c}}}{m} ,\end{equation}\]

where the first term leads to pitch angle diffusion by electromagnetic field tensor, without changing the particle energy. The second term is the local coordinate, which changes with time and accelerates particle. The quantities with hat represent those in local inertial frame of particle.

\[\begin{equation} \Delta p^t(\Delta \tau) = [e^t_{\hat{a}}(\Delta \tau)- e^t_{\hat{a}}(0)]\hat{p}^{\hat{a}}(0) + e^t_{\hat{a}}(\Delta \tau)\int_0^{\Delta\tau} \mathrm{d}\tau_1 \frac{\mathrm d \hat{p}^{\hat{a}}}{\mathrm{d}\tau _1} \end{equation}\]

Here the first term describes Fermi acceleration, and second term is the particle kinetic evoution in its local frame. \(e^t_{\hat{a}}\) is the Vierbein of relativistic transformation.

This framework can reproduce the conclusion of shock acceleration (Section II).
entry.summary: Reading note of Lemoine 2019 PhRvD, the theoretical framework of generatlized Fermi acceleration

entry.title: Blandford-McKee 1976 Reading Note
entry.content:
This post is to take some reading notes of Blandford-McKee 1976 self-similar solution, and derive the main equations in detail.

Relativistic Shock Jump Condition

Define the dimensionless 4-velocity \(u = ds/cd au\), therefore spacial component of u is \(\gamma eta\), and time component is \(1\).

We further define the relative dimensionless velocity \( eta_{ij}\), e.g. \( eta_{1s}\) the relative velocity between shock and upstream unshocked plasma. From SR, we easily get the following relations

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} & eta_{1s} = rac{ eta_{2s}+ eta_{21}}{1+ eta_{2s} eta_{21}}\ & eta_{2s} = rac{ eta_{1s}- eta_{21}}{1- eta_{1s} eta_{21}}\ & eta_{21} = rac{ eta_{1s}- eta_{2s}}{1- eta_{1s} eta_{2s}}\ &\gamma_{1s} = \gamma_{2s}\gamma_{21}(1+ eta_{2s} eta_{21})\ &\gamma_{2s} = \gamma_{1s}\gamma_{21}(1- eta_{1s} eta_{21})\ &\gamma_{21} = \gamma_{1s}\gamma_{2s}(1- eta_{1s} eta_{2s})\ &u_{1s} = \gamma_{2s}\gamma_{21}( eta_{21}+ eta_{2s})\ &u_{2s} = \gamma_{1s}\gamma_{21}( eta_{1s}- eta_{21})\ &u_{21} = \gamma_{1s}\gamma_{2s}( eta_{1s}- eta_{2s}) \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

This is useful to obtain jump conditions in upstream rest frame. The shock needs to satisfy mass, momentum and energy conservation. In shock frame, the conservation condition could be derived from \(\partial_x T^{1 u} = 0\). Obviously we must first have the particle number conservation

\[ egin{equation} \langle nu angle = \langle n\gamma eta angle = 0 \end{equation}\]

Then from \(\partial_x T^{00} = 0\) follows the energy conservation condition:

\[ egin{equation} \langle \gamma^2 h eta angle = \langle \gamma h u angle = 0 .\end{equation}\]

From \(\partial_x T^{01} = 0\), we have the momentum conservation:

\[ egin{equation} \langle \gamma^2 eta^2 h +p angle = \langle hu^2+p angle = 0 \end{equation}\]

here \(h\) is the enthalpy in unit volume in fluid rest frame. We need to note that the \(n, p, e , h\) are all quantities in the fluid rest frame. The relativistic transformation is contained in the dimensionless 4-speed.

Rankine-Hugoniot Condition for Cold upstream

Cold upstream means that \(e_1 = ho_1 c^2, p_1= 0\). Thus from the equation of state \(p = (\hat{\gamma} - 1)(e - ho c^2)\), there is \( rac{p}{n} = (\hat{\gamma}-1)( rac{e}{n}-mc^2)\). If the internal energy at upstream \(e_1- ho c^2=0\), since the \(e/n\) is Lorentz invariant, we have

\[ egin{equation} rac{e_2}{n_2} = \gamma_{21} m c^2 \end{equation}\]

Therefore,

\( rac{p_2}{n_2} = (\hat{\gamma}-1)(\gamma-1) mc^2\).

From the energy conservation \(\gamma_{1s} h_1/n_1=\gamma_{2s} h_2/n_2\), we have \( egin{equation} rac{\gamma_{1s}}{\gamma_{2s}} = \hat{\gamma}(\gamma_{21} -1)+1 \end{equation}\)

Keep this in mind and substitute it into

\[\gamma_{2s} = \gamma_{1s}\gamma_{21}(1- eta_{1s} eta_{21}),\]

eliminate \(\gamma_{2s}\) and after a bit complicated formulation we get

\[ egin{equation} \gamma_{1s}^2 = rac{(\gamma_{21} + 1)[\hat{\gamma}(\gamma_{21}-1)+1]^2}{\hat{\gamma}(2-\hat{\gamma} )(\gamma_{21}-1)+2}. \end{equation}\]

From Lorentz factor, we can directly write the dimensionless 4-velocity \(u^2 = \gamma^2 eta^2 = \gamma^2-1\)

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} u_{1s}^2 = & rac{(\gamma_{21} - 1)(\gamma_{21}\hat{\gamma}+1)^2}{(\gamma_{21}-1)+2}\ u_{2s}^2 =& rac{(\gamma_{21} - 1)(\hat{\gamma}-1)^2}{(\gamma_{21}-1)+2} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

Therefore, from \(u_{2s} n_{2} = u_{1s}n_1\), the compression ratio is

\[ egin{equation} rac{n_2}{n_1} = rac{\hat{\gamma}\gamma_{21}+1}{\hat{\gamma}-1} \end{equation}\]

These are the Rankine-Hugoniot conditions of relativistic shock, see eq. (3-5) in BM76.

Energy-Momentum Tensor

The energy-momentum tensor could be expressed in the following form

\[ egin{equation} T^{\mu u} = (e+p) u^\mu u^ u + p \eta ^{\mu u}, \end{equation}\]

where \(e\) is the energy density (internal energy + rest mass), \(p\) is the pressure, \(u = \gamma( 1, eta_x, eta_y, eta_z)\) the dimensionless 4-velocity, \(\eta = (-1,1,1,1)\) the Minkowski metric.

Specifically, if a relativistic fluid is moving with \( eta\) in \(x\) direction, the complete matrix form of EM Tensor is

\[ egin{equation} T^{\mu u} = \left( egin{matrix} \gamma^2h-p & \gamma^2 eta h & 0&0\ \gamma^2 eta h & \gamma^2 eta^2 h +p & 0 & 0 \ 0&0&p&0\ 0&0&0&p \end{matrix} ight) \end{equation}\]

Eq. (11) and (12) are in the spherical coordinate with angular symmetry. Thus \(\eta = (-1,1,r^2,r^2\sin^2 heta)\) and \(u = \gamma(1, eta,0,0)\). We can now calculate the derivative of the EM Tensor,

\[ egin{aligned} &\partial_0T^{00} = rac{\partial (e+p)\gamma^2}{\partial t} - rac{\partial p}{\partial t}\ &\partial_0T^{0r} = rac{\partial (e+p)\gamma^2 eta}{\partial t}\ &\partial_r T^{r0} = rac{1}{r^2 } rac{\partial}{\partial r } \left[r^2 (e+p)\gamma^2 eta ight]\ &\partial_r T^{rr} = rac{1}{r^2 } rac{\partial}{\partial r } \left[r^2 (e+p)\gamma^2 eta^2 ight] + rac{1}{r^2 } rac{\partial}{\partial r } \left(r^2p ight) \end{aligned}\]

From the energy and momentum conservation, i.e. \( abla _{\mu} T^{\mu u} = 0\). Sum up the corresponding derivatives, for \( u = 0\), we get

\[ egin{equation} rac{\partial}{\partial t } rac{e+p eta^2}{1- eta^2}+ rac{1}{r^2 } rac{\partial}{\partial r } rac{r^2(e+p) eta}{1- eta^2}=0, \end{equation}\]

same as eq. (11).

For \( u=1\),

\[ egin{equation} rac{\partial }{\partial t} rac{(e+p) eta}{1- eta^2}+ rac{1}{r^2 } rac{\partial}{\partial r } rac{r^2 (e+p) eta^2}{1- eta^2} + rac{\partial p}{\partial r} + rac{2p}{r}. \end{equation}\]

There seems to be an additional \({2p}/{r}\) compared to eq. (12) of BM76.

With \(e = 3p\) the ultra-relativistic approximation for equation of state, and using \(\gamma = 1/\sqrt{1- eta^2}\), we expand eq (11-12,14-15).

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} (4\gamma^2-1) rac{\partial p}{\partial t} + 8\gamma p rac{\partial \gamma}{\partial t } + 4\gamma^2 eta rac{\partial p }{\partial r} + 4p(2\gamma eta + rac{1}{\gamma eta}) rac{\partial \gamma }{\partial r }+ rac{8p\gamma^2 eta}{r}= 0&\hspace{2em} ext{(eq. 11)}\ 4 \gamma^2 eta rac{\partial p }{\partial t } + 4p(2\gamma eta + rac{1}{\gamma eta}) rac{\partial \gamma }{\partial t } + (4 \gamma^2 -3 ) rac{\partial p}{ \partial r } + 8p\gamma rac{\partial \gamma }{\partial r} + rac{8p(\gamma^2-1)}{r } = 0&\hspace{2em} ext{(eq. 12)}\ \ (\gamma^2-1) rac{\partial p}{\partial t} + 4 \gamma p rac{\partial \gamma}{\partial t } + 4 eta p\gamma rac{\partial \gamma}{\partial r} + eta \gamma^2 rac{\partial p }{\partial r }= 0&\hspace{2em} ext{(eq. 14)}\ 3\gamma^2 rac{\partial p}{\partial t} + 4 \gamma p rac{\partial \gamma }{\partial t } + 3 eta \gamma^2 rac{\partial p}{\partial r } + (4\gamma eta p + rac{4p}{\gamma eta}) rac{\partial \gamma}{\partial r} + rac{8\gamma^2 p eta}{r} = 0&\hspace{2em} ext{(eq. 15)} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

No additional approximations are made in the expansion above. Eq. 14 could be derived by combining eq. 11-12 and eliminate the \(p/r\) term. Eq. 15 is obtained by adding eq. 14 with eq. 11.

Therefore,

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{d}{dt}(p\gamma^4) = &\gamma^2 rac{\partial p }{\partial t}&\hspace{2em} ext{(eq. 14)}\ rac{d}{dt}\ln(p^3\gamma^4) = &- rac{4}{r^2} rac{\partial}{\partial r}(r^2 eta)&\hspace{2em} ext{(eq. 15)} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

From the particle conservation \( rac{\partial n'}{\partial t} = - rac{1}{r^2} rac{\partial }{\partial r }(r^2 n' eta),\) we could yield \( rac{dn'}{dt} = - rac{n'}{r^2} rac{\partial r^2 eta}{\partial r} = rac{n'}{4} rac{d}{dt}\ln(p^3\gamma^4)\)

Thus

\[ rac{4}{n'} rac{dn'}{dt} = rac{n'}{4} rac{d}{dt}\ln(p^3\gamma^4)\]

which turns into \( egin{equation} rac{d}{dt}\left( rac{p^3\gamma^4}{n'^4} ight) = rac{d}{dt}\left( rac{p}{n^{4/3}} ight) = 0 \end{equation}\)

Self-Similar Solution of Adiabatic Blast Wave

The energy between R0 and R1 is \(E = \int_{R_0}^{R_1} 16 \pi p\gamma^2 r^2 dr\). In the coefficient,\(4\pi r^2\) is due to spherical coordinate, \(4\gamma^2p\) is the shocked energy density. Assuming an adiabatic expanding blast wave, the total energy is conserved \(E \propto R^3\Gamma^2\).

Further assume \(\Gamma \propto t^{-m}\) with \(m > -1\), first expand \( eta\) with \(\Gamma\) to \(O(\Gamma^{-2})\)

\[R = \int eta dt = t\left[1- rac{1}{2(m+1)\Gamma^2} ight].\]

BM76 chose the self similar variable as

\[ egin{equation} \chi = [1+2(m+1) \Gamma^2]\left(1- rac{r}{t} ight) \end{equation}\]

The post-shock fluid could write as

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} p =& rac{2}{3}h_1\Gamma^2 f(\chi)\ \gamma_{21}^2 =& rac{1}{2}\Gamma g(\chi)\ n' =& 2n_1\Gamma^2 h(\chi) \end{aligned}, \end{equation}\]

where \(\Gamma = \gamma_{1s}\) is the shock Lorentz factor and \(\Gamma^2 = 2 \gamma_{21}^2\) in the ultra-relativistic limit. \(n'\) is seen from the upstream rest frame and \(n'= \gamma n_2\).

Then we can substitute the old variables \(r,t\) with new variables \(\Gamma^2, \chi\). Be careful here that \(\Gamma^2 \propto t^{-m}\) and is independent upon \(r\). Then we have the elements of Jacobi Matrix,

\[ egin{aligned} t rac{\partial \Gamma^2}{\partial t} =& -m\Gamma^2\ t rac{\partial \Gamma^2 }{\partial r} = &0\ t rac{\partial\chi}{\partial t} =& (m+1)(2\Gamma^2-\chi)+1\ t rac{\partial\chi}{\partial r} =& -[1+2(m+1)\Gamma^2] \end{aligned}\]

Specially, we have substituted \(\Gamma^2 =A t^{-m}\) to compute \(t rac{\partial\chi}{\partial t}\). The old derivatives are now

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} & rac{\partial}{\partial\ln t} = -m rac{\partial}{\partial \ln \Gamma^2}+ [(m+1)(2\Gamma^2-\chi)+1] rac{\partial }{\partial\chi}\ &t rac{\partial}{\partial r} = -[1+2(m+1)\Gamma^2] rac{\partial }{\partial\chi}\ & rac{d}{d\ln t} = -m rac{\partial}{\partial \ln \Gamma^2}+ (m+1)\left( rac{2}{g}-\chi ight) rac{\partial }{\partial\chi} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

The third equation is from convective derivative \(d/dt = \partial_t + eta_{21}\partial_r\). There is the function \(g\) because of the \( eta_{21}\).

Now we have the new derivatives. Just substitute them into (14-16), and only keep the terms with highest order of \(\Gamma^2\). Solve the linear equations and we get the self similar solution of adiabatic blast wave

\[ egin{equation} egin{aligned} rac{1}{g} rac{d \ln f}{d\chi} =& rac{8(m-1)-(m-4)g\chi}{(m+1)(4-8g\chi+g^2\chi^2)}\ rac{1}{g} rac{d \ln g}{d\chi} =& rac{(7m-4)-(m+2)g\chi}{(m+1)(4-8g\chi+g^2\chi^2)}\ rac{1}{g} rac{d \ln h}{d\chi} =& rac{2(9m-8)-2(5m-6)g\chi + (m-2) g^2\chi^2}{(m+1)(4-8g\chi+g^2\chi^2)(2-g\chi)} \end{aligned} \end{equation}\]

There is no \(h\) in eq (14,15), so we could first align these two equations and solve derivative of \(f,g\).
entry.summary: A derivation of Blandford-McKee 1976 self similar solution for relativistic blast wave
